text: Adebisi Akanji (born 1930s) is a Nigerian artist. == Early life and education == In his early life he worked as a bricklayer, and first began to create sculptures as part of a competition to sculpt cement animals based on traditional architectural elements in Yoruba houses. == Career == Akanji is best known for his open-faced cement screens and other sculptural work. He has also worked in textiles. His work often illustrates themes from Yoruba folklore. In collaboration with Susanne Wenger, he worked for a decade on the Osun shrine in Osogbo, Nigeria, and is responsible for many of the shrine's sculptural elements.Official Opening of the Arch of the Flying Tortoise, Osun- Osogbo, Aug. 2015 on susannewenger-aot.org thumb| A cement sculpture by Adebisi Akanji at the entrance to the house of Susanne Wenger. ==References== == External links == Category:20th-century Nigerian sculptors Category:Yoruba artists Category:1930s births Category:Living people Category:Nigerian bricklayers Category:21st-century Nigerian artists Category:21st-century sculptors Category:Male sculptors Category:Year of birth missing (living people)
